plants.name: Rhododendron ponticum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub known for its large clusters of fragrant, tubular flowers. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in woodland edges and heathlands.
plants.location: Western Europe, particularly mild Atlantic climates
plants.funFact: Rhododendron ponticum can be invasive outside its native range, especially in parts of the UK and Ireland.

plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous tree famous for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that appear before the leaves, heralding spring's arrival in many temperate gardens.
plants.location: Cultivated widely in temperate regions including North America, Europe, and parts of Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer Magnolia was created by crossing Magnolia denudata and Magnolia liliiflora in the early 19th century.

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A striking tropical tree with vivid red, spiky flowers attracting hummingbirds and pollinators. It grows well in subtropical and tropical climates.
plants.bloomingSeason: Spring to early summer (September to April in Southern Hemisphere, including April)
plants.location: Native to South America, blooming in Southern Hemisphere spring regions
plants.funFact: Erythrina crista-galli is Argentina's national flower, symbolizing resilience and beauty.

plants.name: Anemone nemorosa
plants.description: A delicate spring wildflower of deciduous woodlands, producing star-shaped blooms that carpet forest floors in early spring.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Europe and Asia
plants.funFact: Wood Anemones spread primarily through underground rhizomes, allowing for large colonies to form.
